Just repeating Eric Hougland's announcement of the winners of The Griddies from yesterday:

Eric wrote:

John Ezra, Marshall Walthew and I are pleased to announce the winners and runners-up for the 2025 Griddies (f/k/a the Puzzle of the Year Awards):

Best Early Week Puzzle: Winner August 27 (Zhou Zhang), Runner-Up April 1 (Sande Milton)

Best Thursday Puzzle: Winner October 2 (Aidan Deshong); Runner-Up July 17 (Sam Brody)

Congratulations to all the winners and almost-winners!

Groundhog Day is one of my favorite movies, with deep western Pennsylvania roots. I can watch it -- and have -- over and over, getting something new out of it every time (which is one of the points of the movie). 

Here's a mediocre joke:

One Easter morning, the preacher gathered the children of the church in the front of the sanctuary for the weekly children's sermon. He began with a thematically appropriate question.

"Children, today is Easter Sunday. What do we celebrate on Easter?"

One girl spoke up quickly: "We remember our mothers and how much we love them."

"No, that's not quite right," the pastor replied. "You're thinking of Mother's Day."

Then, an eager boy took a shot: "Easter is a time when we say 'thank you' to God for all the good things in our lives."

"We can always say 'thank you' to God," the pastor said, beginning to worry how these kids could know so little. "But, you're thinking of Thanksgiving, not Easter. Can anyone tell me the meaning of Easter?"

A girl in a fancy Easter dress raised her hand confidently. "Easter," she said tentatively, "is the day when we remember that Jesus died on the cross for our sins. Then he was buried in the tomb. On Easter morning, God rolled the stone away and Jesus came out of the tomb."

"Excellent," cried the relieved pastor.

"And then," the girl continued, "Jesus looked and saw his shadow, so he went back into the tomb and there were six more weeks of winter!"

I finally reached a section of The Magic Mountain that had me skimming rather than raptly reading each paragraph.

Research, (H tries to find the answer to "What is Life?" by reading obsolete books on anatomy, biology, and physiology), followed  by Todentanz, (H persuades J to join him as he presents flowers to a long series of patients facing imminent death), are both repetitive and introduce terminology and characters which will shortly leave the story.

As a relief, I turned to some critics.  I found two readings that I'll keep in mind as I approach the second half of the book.

1. The Magic Mountain is an "Anti-Bildungsroman".  Hans takes trip which changes his world, meets new people with new ideas, has many new experiences but "learns" nothing and remains the same person he was before he left Hamburg.

2.  Hans makes a "Hero's Journey" facing illness, (sacrifice), and mortality, (visit to the Underworld), to become healthy enough to face Death personally as  "A Soldier, and Brave".

I'll reserve judgement until I finish the book.
Now that's how you do it! Great job with this one!

commentBody: This grid is a good example of the fuzzy Monday line between cute and remedial.

Marvelous Monday grid that had me cracking up. Happy Groundhog Day, Crosslandia! Here is a compilation of clips from GROUNDHOG DAY for those who haven‚Äôt seen it (I can‚Äôt imagine that, but just in case) üòâ https://youtu.be/lZO3OjrmJQg?si=gcMZlp_DotUsmekw Thank you, John and Colin. That was the bee‚Äôs knees.

"Growing up in the 1990s,"

//cries

I liked this, mostly because of how my solve unfolded.

On Mondays I don't usually pay attention to the theme, and I quite mindlessly hop from clue to clue not looking at the greater picture. The first themed clue was a gimme, but the other two were not. I actually grew annoyed: "%@$@$ trivia-based themes!" I thought.

Now, the fill, extremely straightforward in the upper third of the puzzle, began to give me (minor) trouble in the lower two thirds. In fact, I was forced to take a step back and look at the grid as a whole - and then I was struck by the realization of the repetitive theme. Wow! To be surprised? On a Monday, of all days? That was quite something!

What's most important, to me, is that I still solved in quite typical Monday time. I really don't enjoy toughened-up Mondays (I consider those a betrayal of solver-constructor-editor trust) - happily this wasn't one, and yet I found it unusual. Very cool.

I also liked the somewhat perverse clue for SOLO. I find duets kind of special. Taking away one of the performers in a duet changes everything. Mathematically the result may be a solo, but artistically it is a complete transformation. I love it when math, my nemesis, fails to describe what's happening in any sense that matters to living, breathing people ü§£

(If you find the final paragraph confusing, I don't blame you - the ramblings of Andrzej are often understood by him only. I would have expressed it better in Polish...)

Best Monday I can remember!
Wow, you can say that again!
Best Monday I can remember!
Wow, you can say that again!

When I lived in Kenosha, I'd take occasional trips out to places in northern Illinois, like the IL RR Museum, and often those routes took me through Woodstock, IL, where GHD was partially filmed. I had heard that there was a plaque placed on the sidewalk on the town square, and one time I stopped to take a look. It's on the north side of the square, on the north side of the street, and has a "shoe print" and the words "Bill Murray stepped here".

Nice puzzle, and very appropriate for the date, and a nice reminder of past adventures. Thanks, gents.

I don't expect they'd be precisely the same length, but 4 hours (66%) longer in German?! What's up with that?

Oh, this forum is crackling today with wit and humor ‚Äì thoroughly entertaining and the perfect chaser to such a feel-good puzzle.  My mood has gone from neutral to soaring!

The musical is great! It‚Äôs sad it didn‚Äôt have a longer Broadway run. I have read it can‚Äôt tour due to complicated staging. I listen to the cast recording often.

Excited to say I'm joining the puzzle team! Arduous hiring process and Will is a mean interviewer but once my notice is served and I've had a small break I'll be the writing three columns per week. Cannot wait to get started.

Well, like many, I‚Äôm sure, when I was midway through filling in the second theme answer, I broke into a huge ‚ÄúHah!‚Äù-based smile.  

Didn‚Äôt matter that the puzzle after that filled in faster because the other theme answers were obvious.  Nope.  Having the theme recall the feel of that marvelous-and-never-forgotten movie on the exact holiday was enough to turn my thumbs up and keep them there.

What a clever puzzle premise!

I liked that the clues were different for each theme answer, echoing the movie, where it was the same day all over again, yet different things were happening.

I also liked the quartet of three-letter answers ending in double-consonants (ITT, ATT, BRR, USS), as well as the prominence of red, with SOLO (as in cup), ROAN, ROJO, and the ‚Äúpainting the town red‚Äù ON A JAG.

Like the movie, this puzzle, to my mind, is a beautiful gem. Congratulations on your debut, Colin, and thank you and John for this day-elevating creation!

It used to be that every day at 5 o‚Äôclock I‚Äôd see a little shadow.
Now, it‚Äôs winter all year long.

We had a three Pete.
Was this a four Phil?

Really enjoyed this one. None of the theme answers were dawning on me just from the clues, but the first couple fell together with some crosses and then the trick finally dawned on me. Always nice to have something just a bit different. And... ... speaking of that - a Thursday from February 2 (!) 2002 by Bob and Sharon Klahn. GROUNDHOG and SIXWEEK were among the theme answers but the most remarkable one was a 16 letter answer that actually extended one square above the top and ran all the way down the center of the puzzle. That clue and answer... "For the outlook, look out for his look out!" PUNXSUTAWNEYPHIL Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/2/1995&g=1&d=D ....

Punxsutawney Phil in Pennsylvania and General Beauregard Lee in Georgia both saw their shadows this morning.

I've yet to hear from Wiarton Willie (Ontario), Fred La Marmotte (Quebec). Shubenacadie Sam (Nova Scotia). or Staten Island Chuck (New York). Let me know what y'all hear from your local critter forecasters.
Very clever!

My only quibble is that Punxsutawney wasn't an answer in the puzzle. I used to love to spell that when I was a kid. I wonder if others not from the east coast are aware of its relationship to the theme?
Fun. But at 60D would argue that ‚ÄúThat girl‚Äù is HER. Think ‚ÄúThe girl‚Äù could solve to SHE.
You know it's Monday, and that there's a sub writing the Wordplay column, when ETON is listed among the "Tricky Clues".

Themes are beyond me. Did not get the repeating thing to match the movie until I read the column.

Also when everything else was filed in I wasted a full seven minutes with E_S/D_SHaTS. Could not see what would make D_S HATS or D_SH aTS or D_ SHaTS or D_SHa TS work until I twigged it‚Äôs ROJO, not ROJa. Not a lot of Spanish over here, French and German were more common in my schools days.

Fun fact-oid about the movie GROUNDHOG DAY: 

Although the movie shows "only" 38 days that Bill Murray's character Phil [of course Phil, like the groundhog] Connors relives, it's estimated that he relived the same day 12,403 times!

When the director Harold Ramis was asked, he originally suggested 10 years, but later joked that it could have been 10,000 years!

Well, at least it's not DONALD/DONALD/DONALD!

If you're going to break all the rules of puzzledom, at least be funny about it -- that's what I say.¬† And for anyone who's seen the movie, this is very, very funny.¬† The fact that the puzzle is appearing on GROUNDHOG DAY is a real coup.¬† 

But we don't need Phil to either see his shadow or not see his shadow -- I never remember which one it is -- because we already know how long the winter of 2026 will last.¬† 

The answer is: forever.

I am wondering, though, what¬†people who have never¬†seen the movie and don't know its premise would think of this puzzle.¬† Answer: They might think that they were losing¬†their everloving minds.

Nonetheless: A terrific idea for February 2nd!
Hilarious-but not surprising-to see Chappell ROAN copying my fashion style at last night's Grammy's.

Oh, ha ha.  Somehow I had managed to forget it's GROUNDHOG DAY.  (I just wrote a short piece for our Village newsletter about vying with GROUNDHOGs for my garden produce there in NE Ohio.  Eight acres to dine on, but only the gourmet goodies growing in my (fenced) plot would do....)

Oh, the puzzle!  
Well, how cute is that?  It can't have been easy to find that many three- and four-letter cross-worthy words to fit into this fun puzzle.  Clever clues re the movie, which we still enjoy; it's on quite often.  Is it really that old??  (Unlike we ourselves, of course, cough cough....)

According to the 140th annual tradition, this signifies six more weeks of winter. The prediction was delivered at roughly 7:25 a.m. to a crowd in frigid, below-zero temperatures. "

I needed NYT to advise me that it is, in fact that day today, as we have no groundhogs in the UK. Hedgehogs, yes, straight up hogs, though we call ‚Äòem pigs. But no groundhogs. They do look cute.

This was a nice lift for me as I‚Äôm feeling pretty miserable having just had an emergency tooth extraction this morning. The pain level  of an exposed nerve was off the chart. The bliss of anaesthesia is starting to lift now, but the pain cannot possibly be worse than I experienced yesterday. The joy of implant v bridge is still to come. I love getting older üò¶

Regarding the constructor notes:
The term "Bucket List" was certainly popularized by the movie, and I believe it was even coined by that screenwriter, but it was released into the wild in 2004, three years before the movie came out. "Earliest Print Usage (2004): The term appeared in Patrick M. Carlisle‚Äôs book Unfair & Unbalanced: The Lunatic Magniloquence of Henry E. Panky."   By the time I started hearing ads for the movie I certainly knew what a bucket list was.

38 down is a terrible clue. Roan horses can be other colors.  Roan is a pattern where the head is solid colored and the body is a mix of white and colored hairs.  See also blue roan.  The red color itself is referred to as chestnut or sorrel, to keep it simple.
One little typo and my shot at a PR for Monday vanished! Loved the theme though, perfect for a Monday!
Four groundhog days equals 54 across. Someone has run out of ideas
Nice easy Monday but what is ONAJAG?

Oh Sisyphean streaks.
We watch the golden stars accumulate.
Our excitement mounts as they increase.
Will we reach our current record?
Will we surpass it?
Letter by letter, clue by clue,
We trudge on.
A new record!
Just one letter ends the streak.
Down to the bottom we go
To start all over again
First comment ever and just to say that I really hope putting DONALD and STENCH next to each other was intentional.

Am I misreading the constructors' notes? They seem to be saying that "groundhog day" originated with the movie. It has been a folk tradition for much longer; Wiki says that it comes from the Pennsylvania Dutch

I grew up in Punxsutawney and I can tell you first hand that the groundhog is actually a dude named Gooch Johnson wearing a gopher suit. He‚Äôs been doing it for years and it never ceases to amuse me that the whole world  believes he‚Äôs actually a groundhog.  Also of note, I was living in Punx when they shot the film and I have a brief cameo in one scene. I play the groundhog and my name is a Gooch Johnson brah

A rather remarkable late answer search result. I was thinking about - "SINGININTHERAIN" and one thing that dawned on me was the string of 4 'IN's. So I went and did a search for answers that might contain at least four 'IN's and.. that led to a rather amazing result. Most of them were in some way take-offs on SINGININTHERAIN. Some examples: SINGININTHEBRAIN SINGININTHEGRAIN STINGININTHERAIN SINNININTHERAIN SINGININTHETRAIN And they all had multiple answers with similar take-offs. A couple of examples - A Thursday from October 13, 2011. Some answers in that one: SINGININTHEBRAIN HOWARDSBEND BOUTOFAFRICA BEASTOFEDEN DOTHEBRIGHTTHING Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=10/13/2011&g=62&d=A And... a Sunday from May 28, 2000 by Richard Silvestri with the title "G Movies" Some answers in that one; SINGININTHEGRAIN GOUTOFAFRICA THEGLOVEDONE GALLABOUTLOVE THEKINGANDGI PLANETOFTHEGAPES Here's that link; https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/28/2000&g=22&d=A I'll post more about the other puzzles tomorrow. ....

commentBody:
@John Carson
You know yourself best, but cryptics come at all levels of difficulty. The thing that strikes non-crypticizers as odd is that each clue comprises two pieces -- one-half is a "regular" clue; the other half is a tricky clue. 
So you must start by figuring out where to split the clue,  then deciphering the tricky half of the clue.
If you think Thursdays are tricky around here, every day is Thursday in Cryptic-landia.  In tougher cryptics, there may be tinkering /in the clue's very words/; so, instead of EARLY, the clue might say 'nearly' (+ N) or 'earl' (- Y) or 'relay' (anagram). So you have to figure out the clue before you set out to figure an answer.
Guaranteed at least two 'Aha!'s per clue. So worth it.

@SBK
Two PS's.
First, if there is tinkering in the clues' words themselves, that would be hinted at or even explained directly in an intro.
 
Second, GAMES World of Puzzles magazine features at least two cryptics per issue. They are addressed to USians (so, no tricky UK-based clues or spellings) and have a brief introduction about tricks.

@SBK

Many thanks for the advice.

@Nina You obviously know what a US crossword looks like. A British-style one, also called a cryptic, has more of a checkerboard pattern; not every letter has a cross. Here's an example of a cryptic: https://www.theguardian.com/crosswords/cryptic/29919 Cryptics are called that because the clues are made up of a definition part and a wordplay part. The combinations used require a lot of getting used to. They involve anagrams, homonyms, reversing the letters, etc. Here are some examples: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptic_crossword#Clueing_techniques It all looks convoluted, but you eventually figure out what the signal words are, and what they signal. ("About" means one word surrounds another, "rising" means write the letters up [in a down answer.]) The NYT also runs cryptics as the second Sunday puzzle about once every two months, alternating with the acrostic, which appears every other week, and a variety of other puzzles. They are not available on the NYT site or app, only the print edition, but xwordinfo.com has a playable version of these puzzles on their site. Unfortunately, you have to be a member (not that expensive), and also, you cannot solve on mobile devices. I once tried a few cryptics a while back just to see if I could do them. I found that with a little effort to understand how they work, I could, but I didn't like the experience, so I never did them again. Hope this helps!

@Nina
Cryptic crosswords - there are far fewer clues but every clue is unique so has to be worked out from scratch, so no synonyms, "fill", few proper names.

There is no symmetry or pattern to the squares, it's not an issue. Anagrams feature quite a lot. Any one clue has maybe one or two crossing clues. 

Many years ago I did The Scotsman crossword with my Dad, who despite leaving school at 14, was a good crossword and chess player. In the shipyards there was always a small group of men who would do both on their break.
@Steve L - yes this was very helpful!  Thanks a lot!  It sounds complicated üòÖ I should try one of these days.

Matematycznie rzecz biorƒÖc, duet pomniejszony o jednƒÖ osobƒô jest wystƒôpem solo. Jednak matematyka tego rachunku nijak nie oddaje tego, co czuje s≈Çuchacz utworu w wykonaniu duetu lub artysty bƒôdƒÖcego solo. Emocjonalny i artystyczny dialog pary ≈õpiewak√≥w tworzy warto≈õƒá wykraczajƒÖcƒÖ poza prostƒÖ arytmetykƒô - to, czego do≈õwiadcza s≈Çuchacz jest prze≈ºyciem zwiƒÖzanym nie tylko z samƒÖ muzykƒÖ i ≈õpiewem, lecz tak≈ºe z relacjƒÖ wykonawc√≥w. Prawdziwa ona jest czy tylko wykreowana na potrzeby utworu? Czy to pojedynek, czy mo≈ºe akt symbiozy, wykraczajƒÖcy swym efektem poza cokolwiek, czego mo≈ºna dokonaƒá solo? Odpowiedzi na te pytania - i to r√≥≈ºne dla r√≥≈ºnych s≈Çuchaczy, a jednak bez wyjƒÖtku prawdziwe, na co pozwala sztuka, choƒá nie matematyka - nie da siƒô wyraziƒá liczbami i znakami rachunku.

userLocation: no longer writing like E. E. Cummings

commentBody:
Below is DeepL's quite good attempt at translating the above. It's a pity one can't appreciate my simple yet refined style without actually speaking Polish...

Mathematically speaking, a duo minus one person is a solo performance. However, the mathematics of this calculation in no way reflects what the listener feels when listening to a piece performed by a duo or a solo artist. The emotional and artistic dialogue between a pair of singers creates a value that goes beyond simple arithmetic ‚Äì what the listener experiences is not only related to the music and singing itself, but also to the relationship between the performers. Is it real or just created for the purposes of the song? Is it a duel, or perhaps an act of symbiosis, the effect of which goes beyond anything that can be achieved solo? The answers to these questions ‚Äì different for different listeners, yet true without exception, as art allows, though mathematics does not ‚Äì cannot be expressed in numbers and mathematical symbols.

@Bill in Yokohama
German translations are always longer than the original English texts, but in my experience more like 10-20% longer.

@Bill in Yokohama

Here's one data point.

Mann's Der Zauberberg is roughly 1000 pp in German.

English translations of The Magic Mountain about 700, 
when the sometimes extensive Introductions are excluded.   I've seen this explained as quirks of German grammar, syntax, and sentence structure but I don't know.

@Bill in Yokohama
Forgive me if this is too obvious, but have you looked at the Table of Contents for each version?. Perhaps the German version contains additional matter. A translator's foreword or notes re translation decisions? Something that was censored in US editions but reinstated abroad?

@Alasdair New York Times, you have an opportunity to run this exact puzzle again tomorrow.  Don‚Äôt waste it.
@Navin R New York Times, you have an opportunity to run this exact puzzle again tomorrow.  Don‚Äôt waste it.

@Bob T. No way was 'bucket list' coined by a screenwriter in 2006. I'm astonished that the online Merriam Webster makes that claim. It's been in the language for more than two decades, more like three or four.

@Pat I dunno; I did a pretty deep dive and I'm not finding any occurrences prior to 2004; have you found some? Any?
==========
"Justin Zackham coined the expression "bucket list" after he wrote his own "List of Things to do Before I Kick the Bucket" and shortened it to "Justin's Bucket List". The first item on his list was to "get a film made at a major studio".
==========
I don't know how it got from him to Patrick M. Carlisle, nor do I know how it grew from there. I imagine it caught on quickly because it's vivid and useful. OED added it in 2013. 

There are a few earlier uses of "bucket list" in discussions of computer programming, but those have nothing to do with things you want to do before you die.

@Bob T.
Thanks for troubling to reply. The Wiki bit leaves me with more questions than answers! (Not that I expect you to provide them!) 
They say he was rescued 'later'. How long is 'later'? How did the searchers even know to look for him? What was his condition? What did he subsist on while buried? Was he re-imprisoned after being rescued?
Astounding story!
@AliS alas, he did :(
